messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 55 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Multi-Agent Disk InspectionResearch supported in part by NSERC Discovery grant.

Paper Abstract: Abstract We consider nùëõn unit-speed mobile agents initially positioned at the center of a unit disk, tasked with inspecting all points on the disk‚Äôs perimeter. A perimeter point is considered covered if an agent positioned outside the disk‚Äôs interior has unobstructed visibility of it, treating the disk itself as an obstacle. For n=1ùëõ1n=1, this problem is referred to as the shoreline problem with a known distance. Isbell [44] derived an optimal trajectory that minimizes the worst-case inspection time for that problem. For n‚â•2ùëõ2n\geq 2 agents, worst-case optimal trajectories were show in [1, 29]. The one agent version of the problem was originally proposed as a more tractable variant of Bellman‚Äôs famous lost-in-the-forest problem [14]. Our contributions are threefold. First, and as a warm-up, we extend Isbell‚Äôs findings by deriving worst-case optimal trajectories addressing the partial inspection of a section of the disk, hence deriving an alternative proof of optimality for inspecting the disk with n‚â•2ùëõ2n\geq 2 agents. Second, we analyze the average-case inspection time, assuming a uniform distribution of perimeter points (equivalent to randomized inspection algorithms). Using spatial discretization and Nonlinear Programming (NLP), we propose feasible solutions to the continuous problem and evaluate their effectiveness compared to NLP solutions. Third, we establish Pareto-optimal bounds for the multi-objective problem of jointly minimizing the worst-case and average-case inspection times. Mobile Agents, Search, Disk, Shoreline Problem

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 55 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 55"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Lower bounds for shoreline searching with 2 or more robots",
        "Search problems",
        "Search theory",
        "The Theory of Search Games and Rendezvous",
        "The expanding search ratio of a graph",
        "Searching: an algorithmic tour",
        "Parallel searching in the plane",
        "Searching with uncertainty",
        "Searching in the plane",
        "Evacuation of equilateral triangles by mobile agents of limited communication range",
        "Linear search by a pair of distinct-speed robots",
        "On the linear search problem",
        "Byzantine fault-tolerant protocols for (n, f)-evacuation from a circle",
        "Minimization problem",
        "Dynamic programming",
        "An optimal search",
        "Lost in a forest (a problem area initiated by the late richard e. bellman)",
        "Algorithms for p-faulty search on a half-line",
        "Deterministic treasure hunt in the plane with angular hints",
        "Wireless evacuation on m rays with k searchers",
        "Group search on the line",
        "A multi-objective optimization problem on evacuating 2 robots from the disk in the face-to-face model; trade-offs between worst-case and average-case analysis",
        "Ipopt: Interior point optimizer",
        "Group search and evacuation",
        "Evacuating robots via unknown exit in a disk",
        "Evacuation from a disc in the presence of a faulty robot",
        "Wireless autonomous robot evacuation from equilateral triangles and squares",
        "Linear search with terrain-dependent speeds",
        "Improved lower bounds for shoreline search",
        "Jump: A modeling language for mathematical optimization",
        "Solving the ants problem with asynchronous finite state machines",
        "How many ants does it take to find the food?",
        "Evacuation of rectilinear polygons",
        "Lost in a forest",
        "Searching for a shoreline",
        "A distributed deterministic spiral search algorithm for swarms",
        "Search games",
        "Triangle evacuation of 2 agents in the wireless model",
        "Evacuating from ‚Ñìpsubscript‚Ñìùëù\\ell_{p} unit disks in the wireless model",
        "Weighted group search on a line & implications to the priority evacuation problem",
        "Bellman‚Äôs escape problem for convex polygons",
        "An alternative solution to the ‚Äúlost at sea‚Äù problem",
        "The minimax path in a search for a circle in a plane",
        "An optimal search pattern",
        "On the two-dimensional cow search problem",
        "On-line search in a simple polygon",
        "On the approximation of shortest escape paths",
        "On the optimality of spiral search",
        "Searching for an axis-parallel shoreline",
        "Overcoming obstacles with ants",
        "Evacuating two robots from two unknown exits on the perimeter of a disk with wireless communication",
        "Reaching a target in the plane with no information",
        "Information complexity of treasure hunt in geometric terrains",
        "Cost vs. information tradeoffs for treasure hunt in the plane",
        "The USSR Olympiad Problem Book: Selected Problems and Theorems of Elementary Mathematics, Part 2, Volume II"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 55 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Multi-Agent Disk InspectionResearch supported in part by NSERC Discovery grant., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
